comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
Why is this different that other CellProcessorAdaptors? All the other ones throw an exception like SuperCsvConstraintViolationException etc. Why is this one adding to an error list?
Also messy handling where the error might be initialised or not. I think this should be removed and cleaned up.

comments.author: Jose Martinez
comments.comment: This is because this class check if we have an error in optional fields, ie, not mandatory ones. We don't want to stop processing the chain in this case and we set the error in the list. But if the list is not initalisated, we throw the error.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
Not sure we should be mocking DateTimeUtils - its a utility class that deals with dates, I think we shoul have an expectdation on the
employeeData.getDateOfCHange result = LOW_DATE
This way we are sure the method under test actually calls the expected method to get the date - currently the use of "any" means you dont have this currently.
Same comment for all other tests that do this.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: I know Rob has said we shouldnt use step names, which I agree. However, if for moment we are using them, I think the step names should be defined inside AbsenceCaseProcessSupport so they can be re-used. Here, they are private constants in a drop down controller, which shouldnt really own them.

comments.author: Rob Say
comments.comment:
Avoid using process step names - it effectively hardcodes the process implementation into code. (there will be multiple other steps where this option should be enabled)
Use Process Phase Enum instead: Managed Leave or Completion

comments.author: Sergio Torres
comments.comment: Shoud I create a new process phase or the absence case dropdown will be available for all Manage Leave Phase?

comments.author: Sergio Torres
comments.comment: close that and I create a jira to implement that, we need to create the facades to check the phase of the process.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Could you add the JIRA reference here for completeness?

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Is there no JEE way to do this? No idea, just wondering....

Use following to avoid runtime casting:
return ImmutableMap.<String, AbsenceCaseAddTimeWizardStepOpened>of(leaveRequestWrapupWidget.getUniqueID(), leaveRequestWrapupWidget);

Are we not basically re-inventing the event listener pattern here?
